title: The power of strategic narrative | Andy Raskin
key_insights: Replace the 'arrogant doctor' pitch structure (problem-solution) with movement-based storytelling that starts with world shifts
Name both the old game and new game concisely to create powerful contrast (e.g., 'software vs cloud', 'opinions vs reality')
Show winners already playing the new game to establish credibility and urgency
Frame your product as a tool to help customers join a movement, not just solve a problem
Use strategic narrative as a filter for product roadmap decisions - features must support the movement
Make slide titles the takeaway, not just labels, to reduce cognitive load for viewers
Strategic narrative works best for B2B enterprise technology companies with complex sales cycles
The second working session in narrative development is always painful but necessary for breakthrough
topics_discussed: Old game vs new game positioning
Naming the stakes and showing winners/losers
Object of the new game identification
Strategic narrative team formation and process
memorable_quotes: This structure really is about defining a movement, and that's very different from, 'Hey, I'm going to solve your problem.'
We get a lot of requests for features and a lot of them are basically about opinions, some way to record opinions. We're not going to do those.
Make the title the takeaway of the slide so that the person looking at it has to do zero work to take away.
frameworks_mentioned: Old game to new game structure
recommended_for: CEOs and founders of B2B enterprise companies
Business leaders in complex technology sales
summary: Andy Raskin shares his strategic narrative framework that helps B2B companies shift from problem-solution pitches to movement-based storytelling. The approach focuses on defining old game vs new game transitions, showing stakes through winners/losers, and positioning products as tools to help customers join winning movements rather than just solve problems.
